G.L. c. 212, \u00a7 4.proposition: The Berkshire Superior Court has subject‑matter jurisdiction over this action pursuant to G.L. c. 212, § 4 because the amount in controversy exceeds $25,000 when considering medical expenses, lost wages, pain and suffering, and other damages.

G.L. c. 223, \u00a7\u00a7 1, 2, and 9.proposition: Venue is proper in Berkshire County under G.L. c. 223, §§ 1, 2, and 9 because the cause of action arose within Berkshire County and the Property where the incident occurred is located at 123 Maple Street, Pittsfield, Berkshire County, Massachusetts.

Mounsey v. Ellard, 363 Mass. 693, 707\u2.proposition: Under Massachusetts law, a landowner or person in control of real property owes a duty of reasonable care to all lawful visitors to prevent foreseeable harm arising from conditions on the land or emanating from it.
Mounsey v. Ellard, 363 Mass. 693, 707\u2.support_reasoning: Mounsey is the landmark Massachusetts case abolishing the invitee/licensee distinction and imposing a general duty of reasonable care to lawful entrants. Although the quoted passage is from a concurrence discussing trespassers, the majority opinion at 363 Mass. 707–09 expressly holds that an occupier owes a duty of reasonable care to all lawful visitors regarding conditions on the land. That directly supports the proposition about Massachusetts law toward lawful visitors, even if the scope toward trespassers remained more limited at that time.
Mounsey v. Ellard, 363 Mass. 693, 707\u2.relevant_excerpt: “We therefore hold that the duty owed by an occupier of land to all lawful visitors is the duty to act as a reasonable person in all the circumstances… The common‑law distinctions between licensees and invitees shall no longer be determinative of the occupier’s duty of care in this Commonwealth.” (Mounsey v. Ellard, 363 Mass. 693, 707–08 (1973).)

Whittaker v. Saraceno, 418 Mass. 196, 19.proposition: A landowner also owes a duty to exercise reasonable care to prevent harm to persons outside the premises caused by artificial or dangerous natural conditions that the landowner knows or should know pose an unreasonable risk.
Whittaker v. Saraceno, 418 Mass. 196, 19.support_reasoning: The opinion deals with a commercial landlord’s duty to protect persons lawfully in common areas from reasonably foreseeable criminal acts of third parties. It does not address any duty owed to persons outside the premises, nor does it discuss artificial or dangerous natural conditions affecting adjacent property or passersby. The cited language is about foreseeability limits on a landlord’s duty within the premises, so it does not support the broader proposition regarding harm to persons outside the land caused by artificial or natural conditions.
Whittaker v. Saraceno, 418 Mass. 196, 19.relevant_excerpt: “The defendant testified that he had a duty to provide security. He was correct because, as evolved, the common law imposes on a commercial landowner a duty to take reasonable precautions to protect persons lawfully in common areas of rental property against reasonably foreseeable risks. See Restatement (Second) of Torts § 360 (1965); Restatement (Second) of Property, Landlord and Tenant, § 17.3 comment 1, at 197 (1977) (unreasonable risk of harm from criminal intrusion dangerous condition).”

Toubiana v. Priestly, 402 Mass. 84, 87\u.proposition: A landowner also owes a duty to exercise reasonable care to prevent harm to persons outside the premises caused by artificial or dangerous natural conditions that the landowner knows or should know pose an unreasonable risk.
Toubiana v. Priestly, 402 Mass. 84, 87\u.support_reasoning: The opinion concerns a landowner’s duty to maintain an internal freight elevator in a reasonably safe condition for lawful visitors and analyzes negligence, obviousness of risk, and foreseeability. It does not address duties owed to persons outside the premises or distinguish between artificial and natural conditions affecting neighboring land or passersby. The cited passages speak only to on-premises conditions and invitees, so the case does not support the proposition about duties to persons outside the land.
Toubiana v. Priestly, 402 Mass. 84, 87\u.relevant_excerpt: “Clearly, the law imposed on this defendant a duty to maintain his property ‘in a reasonably safe condition in view of all the circumstances, including the likelihood of injury to others, the seriousness of the injury, and the burden of avoiding the risk.’ Mounsey v. Ellard, supra, quoting Smith v. Arbaugh’s Restaurant, Inc., 469 F.2d 97, 100 (D.C. Cir. 1972), cert. denied, 412 U.S. 939 (1973). However, the defendant was ‘not obliged to supply a place of maximum safety, but only one which would be safe to a person who exercises such minimum care as the circumstances reasonably indicate.’”

Giusti v. Weston, 165 Mass. 551, 553\u20.proposition: This duty includes the obligation to take reasonable steps to inspect and remedy dangerous trees or branches overhanging areas where people are foreseeably present, such as public walkways.
Giusti v. Weston, 165 Mass. 551, 553\u20.support_reasoning: The opinion concerns whether a voluntary trust settlement can be set aside for mistake, fraud, undue influence, or lack of understanding by the settlor. It deals with burdens of proof and the legal effect of a trust deed, not with premises liability, trees, inspections, or duties regarding overhanging branches and public walkways. Therefore, it does not address, much less support, the asserted duty to inspect and remedy dangerous trees or branches overhanging areas where people are foreseeably present.
Giusti v. Weston, 165 Mass. 551, 553\u20.relevant_excerpt: "The general rule in this Commonwealth is, that a voluntary settlement, when completely executed with no power of revocation reserved, cannot be revoked or set aside except upon proof of mental incapacity, mistake, fraud, or undue influence."

Harvard Furniture Co. v. Wrenn, 192 Mass.raw_text: Harvard Furniture Co. v. Wrenn, 192 Mass. 387, 389–90 (1906)
Harvard Furniture Co. v. Wrenn, 192 Mass.proposition: This duty includes the obligation to take reasonable steps to inspect and remedy dangerous trees or branches overhanging areas where people are foreseeably present, such as public walkways.
Harvard Furniture Co. v. Wrenn, 192 Mass.support_reasoning: The opinion concerns whether a decree for alimony in gross is a “debt” provable against an absentee’s property in the hands of a receiver, and whether it can be allowed without personal notice to the absentee. It does not address premises liability, duties to inspect or maintain land, or obligations relating to dangerous trees or overhanging branches near public walkways. Therefore it does not support the stated proposition about a duty to inspect and remedy dangerous trees or branches.
Harvard Furniture Co. v. Wrenn, 192 Mass.relevant_excerpt: “The principal question in the case is whether this is a debt, within the meaning of the statute. … We are of opinion that the word ‘debts’ in this statute is used in its broad signification, and includes claims like that now before us. The remaining question is whether this debt can be proved against the absentee and allowed against the property in the receiver’s hands without personal notice to the absentee.”

Dos Santos v. Coleta, 465 Mass. 148, 154.proposition: Defendant’s failure to remedy the hazardous condition over a prolonged period constitutes a failure to exercise the reasonable care expected of a landowner under Massachusetts law.
Dos Santos v. Coleta, 465 Mass. 148, 154.support_reasoning: The opinion directly addresses a landowner’s duty to remedy a hazardous condition, even when it is open and obvious, where the landowner has created and maintained that danger and can anticipate that lawful entrants will encounter it. The court holds that maintaining the trampoline-pool setup, knowing it was dangerous and that people were using it that way over time, could constitute a breach of the duty of reasonable care. This aligns with the proposition that prolonged failure to remedy such a hazard is a failure to exercise the reasonable care expected of a landowner under Massachusetts law.
Dos Santos v. Coleta, 465 Mass. 148, 154.relevant_excerpt: “A landowner, though, ‘is not relieved from remedying an open and obvious danger where [the landowner] “can and should anticipate that the dangerous condition will cause physical harm to the [lawful visitor] notwithstanding its known or obvious danger.”’… Here, Jose set up a trampoline immediately adjacent to a two-foot-deep pool… He knew that the pool warned against jumping of any kind, and he knew that the setup was dangerous… Far from failing to warn… Jose actively facilitated this improper and highly dangerous use… On these facts, a jury were entitled to conclude that the defendants owed a duty of care — specifically a duty to remedy — despite the open and obvious nature of the danger.”

Papadopoulos v. Target Corp., 457 Mass..proposition: Defendant’s failure to remedy the hazardous condition over a prolonged period constitutes a failure to exercise the reasonable care expected of a landowner under Massachusetts law.
Papadopoulos v. Target Corp., 457 Mass..support_reasoning: The opinion abolishes the natural/unnatural accumulation rule and replaces it with a general reasonable care standard for snow and ice, but it does not hold or clearly state that a prolonged failure to remedy a hazardous condition, by itself, constitutes a breach of that duty. The discussion of time focuses on how prolonged non-removal could transform a natural into an unnatural accumulation under the old rule and on reasonable notice, not on a per se rule that extended duration automatically equals a failure to exercise reasonable care. Thus, the case does not specifically support the proposition as framed.
Papadopoulos v. Target Corp., 457 Mass..relevant_excerpt: Under this traditional premises liability standard, a fact finder will determine what snow and ice removal efforts are reasonable in light of the expense they impose on the landowner and the probability and seriousness of the foreseeable harm to others. … The snow removal reasonably expected of a property owner will depend on the amount of foot traffic to be anticipated on the property, the magnitude of the risk reasonably feared, and the burden and expense of snow and ice removal.

Wynn v. Sullivan, 294 Mass. 562, 565\u20.proposition: Defendant cannot avoid liability by characterizing the incident as solely due to weather, because the storm was a typical summer thunderstorm and the dangerous condition of the Subject Branch existed long beforehand and was known or should have been known to Defendant.
Wynn v. Sullivan, 294 Mass. 562, 565\u20.support_reasoning: The opinion in Wynn v. Sullivan deals with premises liability duties owed to a police officer/licensee and with whether statutory elevator-safety violations create a civil cause of action. It does not involve weather, storms, falling branches, or any discussion about a defendant attempting to avoid liability by attributing an incident to weather conditions. The proposition about a typical summer thunderstorm and a dangerous tree branch is unrelated to the issues or holding in this case, so the citation does not support that proposition.
Wynn v. Sullivan, 294 Mass. 562, 565\u20.relevant_excerpt: Moreover, in this Commonwealth, contrary to the rule prevailing in many jurisdictions, violation of a criminal statute of this general class does not ordinarily in and of itself, independently of common law duties, give rise to a civil cause of action. Such a statute has that effect only when by its express terms or by clear implication that appears to have been the legislative intent. That there was no such intent as to one of the very statutes here involved was decided in Palmigiani v. D’Argenio, 234 Mass. 434, and again with full discussion in Garland v. Stetson, 292 Mass. 95, 100, a case very similar to this.

Lane v. Atlantic Works, 111 Mass. 136, 1.proposition: Defendant cannot avoid liability by characterizing the incident as solely due to weather, because the storm was a typical summer thunderstorm and the dangerous condition of the Subject Branch existed long beforehand and was known or should have been known to Defendant.
Lane v. Atlantic Works, 111 Mass. 136, 1.support_reasoning: The opinion discusses proximate cause and intervening acts, holding that a defendant remains liable when an intervening third-party act is foreseeable and does not break causation. It does not address storms, weather, or the inability to avoid liability by labeling an incident as due solely to a (typical) thunderstorm, nor does it discuss a long‑existing dangerous condition vis‑à‑vis weather. Thus, using this case for the specific weather‑related proposition overreads its actual holding, even though its general proximate‑cause reasoning is analogous.
Lane v. Atlantic Works, 111 Mass. 136, 1.relevant_excerpt: "In actions of this description, the defendant is liable for the natural and probable consequences of his negligent act or omission. The injury must be the direct result of the misconduct charged; but it will not be considered too remote if, according to the usual experience of mankind, the result ought to have been apprehended. The act of a third person, intervening and contributing a condition necessary to the injurious effect of the original negligence, will not excuse the first wrongdoer, if such act ought to have been foreseen."

Jupin v. Kask, 447 Mass. 141, 147\u20135.proposition: The risk that a compromised tree branch might fall during a normal storm and injure a pedestrian on the sidewalk beneath it is precisely the type of harm that makes Defendant’s conduct negligent and was reasonably foreseeable under the circumstances.
Jupin v. Kask, 447 Mass. 141, 147\u20135.support_reasoning: The case deals with negligent storage of firearms and the foreseeability that an unstable person with unsupervised access would steal a gun and commit a violent crime. It does not involve premises liability, trees, storms, or falling branches, and its foreseeability analysis is specific to criminal misuse of firearms as dangerous instrumentalities. Therefore it provides no authority for the proposition about a compromised tree branch falling in a normal storm and injuring a pedestrian.
Jupin v. Kask, 447 Mass. 141, 147\u20135.relevant_excerpt: "As in Pine Manor, the risk in the instant case — that a mentally unstable and violent person, to whom unfettered and unsupervised access to Kask’s home was granted, would take a gun from that home and shoot someone — was both foreseeable and foreseen. ... At the very least, Kask should have foreseen that Jason ... might use his unsupervised access to the house to take a weapon from the basement gun cabinet, and subsequently use this weapon in the commission of a violent crime."

Poskus v. Lombardo\u2019s of Randolph, I.raw_text: Poskus v. Lombardo’s of Randolph, Inc., 423 Mass. 637, 639–40 (1996)
Poskus v. Lombardo\u2019s of Randolph, I.proposition: The risk that a compromised tree branch might fall during a normal storm and injure a pedestrian on the sidewalk beneath it is precisely the type of harm that makes Defendant’s conduct negligent and was reasonably foreseeable under the circumstances.
Poskus v. Lombardo\u2019s of Randolph, I.case_name: Poskus v. Lombardo's of Randolph, Inc.
Poskus v. Lombardo\u2019s of Randolph, I.support_reasoning: The quoted concurrence states that the plaintiff’s injuries were *not* within the reasonably foreseeable risk of harm created by the defendant’s negligence. That is the opposite of the claimed proposition, which asserts that the harm was precisely the type of reasonably foreseeable risk making the defendant negligent. Thus, this case passage contradicts rather than supports the proposition about foreseeability of the falling tree branch injury.
Poskus v. Lombardo\u2019s of Randolph, I.relevant_excerpt: "I concur in the view that ‘[t]he facts would not warrant a jury’s finding that the plaintiff[’]s injuries were within the reasonably foreseeable risk of harm created by Lombardo’s negligence.’ Ante at 640-641."

Rodrigues v. Scudder Bay Syndicate, 387.raw_text: Rodrigues v. Scudder Bay Syndicate, 387 Mass. 941, 944–45 (1983)
Rodrigues v. Scudder Bay Syndicate, 387.proposition: Plaintiff is entitled to recover compensatory damages for medical expenses, lost wages, pain and suffering, and all other losses proximately caused by Defendant’s negligence, pursuant to Massachusetts common law.

Goltz v. Stop & Shop, Inc., 413 Mass. 88.raw_text: Goltz v. Stop & Shop, Inc., 413 Mass. 88, 91–92 (1992)
Goltz v. Stop & Shop, Inc., 413 Mass. 88.proposition: Plaintiff is entitled to recover compensatory damages for medical expenses, lost wages, pain and suffering, and all other losses proximately caused by Defendant’s negligence, pursuant to Massachusetts common law.
Goltz v. Stop & Shop, Inc., 413 Mass. 88.support_reasoning: The opinion provided is Commonwealth v. Angelone, a criminal case about lack of criminal responsibility and the effect of intoxication on an insanity defense. It does not address civil negligence, compensatory damages, or the categories of damages recoverable under Massachusetts common law. Therefore, it does not support the proposition about a plaintiff’s entitlement to compensatory damages for medical expenses, lost wages, and pain and suffering in a negligence action.
Goltz v. Stop & Shop, Inc., 413 Mass. 88.relevant_excerpt: The legal principles involved are not disputed or complicated. The prosecution has the burden, when the evidence raises the issue, to prove beyond a reasonable doubt that the defendant was criminally responsible for his conduct. It must, therefore, prove beyond a reasonable doubt, pursuant to the McHoul standard, that the defendant did not lack the substantial capacity to appreciate the wrongfulness of his conduct or to conform his conduct to the requirements of law as a result of a mental disease or defect.

G.L. c. 231, \u00a7 6D.proposition: Plaintiff incurred approximately $1,200 in reasonable and necessary medical expenses related to evaluation and treatment of her injuries.

G.L. c. 231, \u00a7 6B.proposition: Plaintiff is also entitled to statutory prejudgment interest on any judgment at the rate of 12% per annum from the date of commencement of this action, pursuant to G.L. c. 231, § 6B.

G.L. c. 231, \u00a7 85.proposition: G.L. c. 231, § 85 (comparative negligence), which provides that Plaintiff’s contributory negligence, if any, does not bar recovery unless it exceeds Defendant’s negligence, and that damages shall be diminished in proportion to Plaintiff’s negligence, if applicable.
